title: Does 10,000 hour rule mentioned in Outliers (2008 book) actually work? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, actually not, unless you plan your practice in a phased manner using the principles of Deliberate Practice. This is classic case of scientific research made to look interesting and simple without complete understanding of the factors that lead to the original conclusion of the research From one of my recent answers on this topic : Jitin Nair's answer to It is said you need 10,000 hours to master a skill. If you spend 3 hours a day acquiring a skill, how many days does it take to spend 10,000 hours at it? But the important question one can ask here is will performing the same activity for over 10,000 hours make you an expert? Probably not. Anders Ericsson discussed the idea of ‘Deliberate Practice’ [1, 3] that speaks of planned approach to practice. This theme was explored by the Freakonomics podcast recently [4] (if you haven’t heard it before I would highly recommend it) In the episode, an American psychologist tried an experiment where she pushed herself to sing (something she wanted to do since childhood but could not pursue earlier) and learning to do so in a planned, phased manner. She trained for more than a year, and proceeded to not only get better at singing professionally but finally realized her childhood dream, and she released a record [5] Bottomline: Don’t take the 10,000 hour rule so seriously. Doing something for 10,000 hours straight will not make you an expert unless you do it in a planned fashion i.e. using methods of ‘Deliberate Practice’ Relevant Links from quoted text above: [1]http://graphics8.nytimes.com/ima... [3] Why expert performance is special and cannot be extrapolated from studies of performance in the general population: A response to criticisms [4] How to Become Great at Just About Anything - Freakonomics [5] Amazon.com: Sus B: Sus B: MP3 Downloads

I want to clarify the pre-conditions underlying the idea that it takes 10,000 hours to develop the skills needed for eminence (not, as is commonly believed, for simple proficiency) in a field, as stated in the answers for this question and perhaps others on Quora as well. Complex ideas are often attenuated and trivialized in our low attention span society. So, let me comment on this one aspect only. The 10,000 hours principle is cited from Malcolm Gladwell’s book, Outliers, which discusses how people attain eminence in their fields. However, the point Gladwell makes is commonly misunderstood. TL;DR 10K hours is not the number of hours needed to become proficient in a field, but the number of hours of concentrated practice needed at a young age for a very talented person to attain eminence in a field. First, this principle does not tell us how to become good at something, but how ppl become one of the very best in their field. Gladwell uses examples such as the Beatles gaining access to long gigs every night in Hamburg or Bill Gates’ private school giving him access to 100s or 1000s of hours using an advanced computer. So, talented people need that many hours to attain eminence, but ppl without talent cannot get there. Further, these studies aren't talking about casual practice, but intense, highly focused sessions where the student repeats work again and again until they can do it perfectly. Gladwell himself claims that his point has been greatly oversimplified. He comments, “There is a lot of confusion about the 10,000 rule that I talk about in Outliers. It doesn't apply to sports. And practice isn't a SUFFICIENT condition for success. I could play chess for 100 years and I'll never be a grandmaster. The point is simply that natural ability requires a huge investment of time in order to be made manifest. Unfortunately, sometimes complex ideas get oversimplified in translation.” (See r/IAmA - Hi, I'm Malcolm Gladwell, author of The Tipping Point, Blink, Outliers and--most recently--David and Goliath: Underdogs, Misfits and the Art of Battling Giants. Ask me anything!). So, yes, it takes commitment as well as talent to become amazingly in some field, but 10K hours is not the only pre-condition. The studies Gladwell cites talk about 10K hours of intense, concentrated practice, not just casual practice. For more info about attaining eminence in the specific field of programming, see Is the 10,000 hours rule true for programmers? 101 Views

It’s a very stupid and dangerous myth. It’s a great example of post hoc ergo propter hoc, which roughly translates to “if this, therefore because of this.” It’s a logical fallacy. The 10,000 hours principle or roughly ten years of eight hours a day worth of deliberate practice is a dangerous myth that simply justifies the ye ole’ “work hard and you can do anything” nonsense that many kids in the 1980s and 1990s got fed. I have read the book Outliers and the primary example used is Bill Gates, who had access to computers at a time when having regular access to computers was unheard of. It asserts that he spent the vast majority of his youth learning computers while others slept (said in your JV coaches voice). It’s total crap. It makes a couple of assumptions that don’t entirely hold up to scrutiny: What does “Mastery” even mean? This is a big one. Is mastery success or is success indicative of mastery? Is Bill Gates really the best programmer, or is he just a very fortunate programmer.It ignores inconvenient facts. Bill Gates father was a patent attorney enabling him access to purchase patents of operating systems when others simply would not have been able to gain that access. Tom Brady didn’t seriously play Football until freshman year, was benched most of that time, made it on Michigan as a 7th man, also benched, and had nowhere near 10,000 hours when he made it to the Patriots.Ignores talent or potential inborn skill. Where does someone like McCaulay Culkin fit into this? By the time he was a star and the biggest name in Hollywood he wasn’t even old enough to have devoted 10,000 hours. What about pro-athletes who we know for a fact are genetically superior in terms of athletic skill and ability.Ignores people who have put in 10,000 hours and not achieved ‘Mastery’. Okay, it was practice but it wasn’t deliberate practice is some class-A grade victim-blaming.Ignores the idea that some ‘masters’ may have gotten credit for others work. They use Mozart at one point, I think, and his father actually wrote most of his early music. Same thing with Prince. However, typically history ignores this, thrusting the credit onto one easily digested figure. This is clearly the case with Bill Gates.Ignores the physical and or psychological ramification for the method. Ask Robo-QB and future drug addict, Todd Marinovich, what a real-life application of this method did to his psyche.Possibly uses dubious examples. Using something like coding might be flawed as almost anyone with average intelligence would probably be reasonably good at certain activities, such as coding or writing, given 10,000 hours of practice.It’s fraught with issues. The basic summation of it could be “if you do something for a long time, you will get good at it”. Thanks Captain Obvious! I come from an arts background. I was just better at drawing than everyone from a very young age. There was no ‘deliberate practice’. It was evidenced in drawings I did before I could form memories. There were drawings I did at 3 and 4 that looked better than what most could draw at 7 or 8. So even simply drawing from some personal experience, no I don’t buy this. I think there’s some use it what might be considered everyday jobs, such as being an office administrator or maybe a bartender, although it’s arguable even those are at the whims of talents and tendencies. In athletics is fraught with issues as some bodies are not built to withstand rigorous training, and deliberate practice can actually harm those people permanently. In the arts, particularly things like acting, most talents are discovered at young ages, sometimes before they even begin training. Chris Hemsworth didn’t start studying acting and improv until after he started acting. I can attest from working on sets and taking acting classes that actors have “abilities” most normal people simply do not possess. There are just too many real-world examples that don’t fit this notion, and even some examples used in the book are misrepresented. So I just don’t find the idea particularly compelling. Seems like pop mathematics.

The 10,000 hour rule is build on a misunderstanding of a study done by Anders Eriksson done some 30 years ago. In this study the best students (of a music Academy in Berlin) had practiced about 10000 hours. Eriksson never made this rule and later he said in one of his Books (Peak) that it is a misunderstanding. First of all these students were not masters yet but still studying. And the point is they all practiced for several hours a day for a period of 5 to 10 years. Normally intense practicing means you practice 700 to 1000 hours at least per year. There are also many people practicing more than 2000 hours a day. To reach a high level of expertis you have to do that for 5 to years. That could be about 10000 hours. But if you spread the 10000 hours over a period of 50 years you will not get very far. I you practice 4 hours a day for five years you can reach quite a high level and maintain that level by only practicing for about one hour a day. I you want to improve from that level you have to practice more again. But that is all approximate. It depends om what an how you are practicing. As a musician there are pieces which need a lot of work. Even if you are at a high level it would not be enough to practice one hour a day and learn a new difficult repertoar. But you can maintain what you have. To improve you need get our of your comfort zone and practice stuff that is a challenge. We don’t usually do that with a lot of things we learned that is why we don’t get better even if we have done it for many years. Usually we reach an acceptable level after about 5 years and we don’t improve from there. (According to Eriksson’s book PEAK) Which is ok. But if you want to master something purposeful and intensiv practice is the way.

It depends on how you conceptualize it.  For example, people tend to think they need to spend 10000 hours honing a single skill, but a lot of jobs require multiple skill sets.  I once went to a talk by the sculptor Al Farrow. He became successful later in life, finally getting his first national tour in his 60s. He went to college studying architectural engineering. He ended up hating it, so he quit his major and devoted his life to making fine art. In order to support himself and his family, he became very good at bartering. He would go into dentists offices and trade paintings for dental checkups. He'd go to restaurants and offer artwork in exchange for the occasional free meal with his family. When he finally created his famous sculpture series that earned him a national tour, he used his fine art skills to come up with the concept and design, his architectural training to figure out how to support the sculptures he wanted to build, and he used his bartering skills to get all the materials he needed. He probably didn't spend 10,000 hours on any of those skills individually. But ultimately he figured out how to combine those skills and produce work that was the result of 10,000+ cumulative hours of development. You have successful musicians who are world class when it comes to performing a single instrument.  You also have successful musicians who know 2 different instruments fairly well and are sort of okay at 3 more, who know a little bit of arranging, who are okay lyricists, who know their way around a recording studio, who know sales, and who are good at public speaking. They're not world class at any of those individual skills, but over all, they're world class musicians, because they figured out how to collage all those skills together to create a complete product.

As others have noted, Gladwell and others that have espoused this rule are all basing this on the work of Anders Ericsson, who studied a number of different high skill activities and came to the conclusion that there is no mastery without focused practice. In other words, no one becomes a virtuoso solely on natural aptitude, many hours of deliberate effort are required as well. I’m going to change tacks here to illustrate a point that many are forgetting. Please meet Ryan Crouser:  Ryan stands 203 cm tall and weighs 141 kg. His specialty is throwing the shot put. This requires a massive amount of explosive strength to do well. Ryan fits this description very well, so much so that he won the Olympic gold in that event in 2016. Here’s another Olympic champion, Eliud Kipchoge:  His specialty is the marathon, and he also won the the gold at Rio. Eliud stands 167 cm, and weighs 57 kg, less than half what Ryan does. His sport demands endurance and efficiency rather than power. It should be fairly apparent that neither of these men would be suited for the other’s sport, but they do share that each is genetically gifted for the needs of their respective sports, and that both have trained very, very long and hard for their selected disciplines. What Gladwell and others have neglected to mention is that natural aptitude plays a part as well. Here’s one more person I’d like to introduce to you:  This is Gary Graffman. Mr Graffman began piano study at age 3, and at age seven was admitted to the Curtis Institute, the most selective collegiate music school in the United States. At age 18, Mr Graffman began has professional career with the Philadelphia Orchestra, went on to have a long, successful career as a pianist, and eventually returned to Curtis where he assumed the role of director and president. By the time he completed his studies at Curtis he no doubt had done his 10,000 hours, but when he was admitted at age 7? Certainly not. Gladwell neglected the importance of natural aptitude. I found out about it when I personally tried to learn the piano. I put in over 1000 hours of effort and never got past the late elementary level. I have a very low level of natural aptitude for music, no amount of focused practice will make me into a mediocre player, let alone a good one. To become a virtuoso, you need a virtuoso’s natural aptitude and a virtuoso’s work ethic. If either is missing, you will not achieve mastery.

Malcolm Gladwell’s Outliers popularized the concept of working 10,000 hours to be an expert by citing the cases of Bill Gates, Beatles, and Mozart. If you read this book, you cannot be faulted for understanding that all you need is 10,000 hours of practice. But just repeating something and hoping that repetition alone will improve one’s performance is a naive thought. The 10,000 rule in Outliers was based on the work of Anders Ericsson and he elaborates that in his book Peak Imagine a time when you learned driving. The first time was scary and you paid attention to everything on the road. It took some time to get comfortable. Now a days you drive from home to work effortlessly without paying conscious attention. Once we reach this level, improvement is hard to come by. A recent paper explored this and concluded, “they were better than when they started. That matched the EEG readouts, which showed an increase in their brains’ electrical activity during the first few days of training. But that spike faded as their performance on the task plateaued” If you are not improving, it’s not because you lack innate talent; it’s because you’re not practicing the right way. Once you understand this, improvement becomes a matter of figuring out what the “right way” is. The “right way”, according to Peak is deliberate practice. In practice this often boils down to purposeful practice with a few extra steps: first, identify the expert performers, then figure out what they do that makes them so good, then come up with training techniques that allow you to do it. Deliberate practice has well-defined, specific goals.is all about putting a bunch of baby steps together to reach a longer-term goal.is focused.involves feedbackrequires getting out of one’s comfort zone(from my review of Peak)

I know I’m late to this party, but here’s my two cents: if you were to look at the majority of “masters” in their respective fields, you would naturally assume that the 10,000 hour rule holds solid. It takes a long time to truly grasp a specific subject or field. There’s so much knowledge, skills and concepts to learn in any endeavor. So on the surface, the rule makes sense. But if you dig deeper, which multiple studies have done, you’ll see that there’s much more to it than just practicing something for 10,000 hours and becoming great. For example, Mozart. Gladwell points out that it took roughly 10 years for him to become a true master musician. But if you know Mozart’s background, you know that he was playing proficiently at 2 years old. He composed his first piece of music between the ages of 5–7. He was playing better at 5 than some people play at 50, with years of experience. You also know that his sister and father were also outstanding musicians, providing the perfect environment for him to learn and flourish. The one thing that Gladwell leaves out: natural talent. This is strike one against the 10,000 rule. I’m sorry if that’s a downer to some, but you cannot rule out the effect that natural aptitude has in achieving success. It’s obvious. Look around you. Almost everybody knows someone who just does something effortlessly, whether it’s sports, music, math, etc. when you ask them how they do it, they say, “ I don’t know, I just do it.” I’m not saying that all it takes is talent to become great. It’s not. But it is essential. As far as deliberate practice is concerned, I’ll probably be in the minority with my opinion. There’s something to be said about the structure of it. Pushing yourself beyond your comfort zone, focusing on specific mechanics of the skill you’re trying to cultivate, getting into the flow, etc. that’s all well and good. But how about this- how many talented people think consciously about these structures? Do they sit down and say, ok I’m going to push my self to the edge of my abilities today, and oh I need to focus on this specific aspect of a technique to really nail it, oh I need to make sure that I get some detailed feedback, etc..? Im going to say no. Do you think Michael Jackson sat down when he started singing and said, “ you know, I had a little trouble going from A1 to A7 on that song, I need to work on that next time.” Or Lebron James in high school saying “ hmm, I need to study the science of jumping so I can dunk”? No. They just did it. It was natural. From there, they maximized their natural abilities with focus, hard work and passion. Most people don’t consciously think about deliberate practice in the way we discuss it here. Anyway, that’s my take on it. Hope it helps!

The 10K hours ‘rule’ which has been interpreted from The Outliers would work for probably more than 95% people for being categorized as ‘experts’ in the area where the hours are focused upon. And it is most certainly, not surprising. To the bare essentials, 10K hours, when broken down, can mean a daily practice of around 2–3 hours for 10 years. Or 4–5 hours of work for 5 years. That is a lot of hard work for a long time.  Hence, if one would notice, The Outliers has quoted a number of studies and experiments to reinforce the long-held and mostly robust intuition of working hard for a long time to become amazing at something. With that in place, like most of the things in life, there are caveats and disclaimers. The 10K hours won’t probably hold true if there is a debilitating condition which prevents mastery over a certain subject. Or if someone tries to brute force his / her way into mastering everything. Example - Working out for 8 hours a day (if one can even do that) and then not maintaining the dietary and sleep requirements isn’t going to transform someone into an Arnold in 4 years. The prescription for 10K hours comes with a set of assumptions/understanding. Once those assumptions/conditions are kept in perspective, the 10K number is just a number.  The only takeaway is that almost everyone who is renowned for their expertise in a certain domain has worked their asses off. It would most probably be the same for us as well.

When I read Malcolm Gladwell’s book, Outliers, many years ago, where he says you need approximately 10,000 hours of purposeful and deliberate practice to master something it made a bit of sense, although I thought it was clearly a gross simplification as some people take way longer than other, some skills take far longer than others, who defines mastery? But he needs to sell books, so fine. But in recent months I’ve realised that he missed something so significant that his 10,000 hours rule is just plain wrong. He missed that achieving mastery is as dependent on the hours as it is on the intensity of them. By intensity I mean the number of engaged hours in a given time period. Hours without intensity is mediocrity. Intensity is why the world junior squash champion has played less squash than me but on a squash court he’d kick my ass, real bad. Intensity is why a Bengali worker learns to speak Malay within 3 months of landing in Malaysia, while I learned French for 10 years but still couldn’t speak it. It’s why my 10 and 12 year old managed to get the top grade in their UK 16+ physics exam 5 months after they started studying physics for the very first time, but when I did the same exam in school it took me 10 years. Intensity is critical because time away from learning means unlearning, or forgetting. 1,000 hours in 1 year is better than 3,000 hours in 10 years. And when you think about it, it’s so bloody obvious. I mean if people get worse at things by not practising it for months, that probably happens for smaller periods too - and it does. Mastery isn’t linearly cumulative as Gladwell implied.

I think the number 10000 was just chosen because its a nice round number. However, the concept itself makes sense, with caveats. The first thing to consider is in the book itself. Malcolm Gladwell made the argument that after a certain point, innate talent has diminishing returns where other factors become more important*. For example, given two people with good hand eye coordination, what will make one of them a better pianist is not some difference in eyesight or fine motor control but how much time and effort they put into practicing. Then we must understand that talent is relative. How do you judge if someone is good at basketball or at piano? You compare them to other people. My point mentioning this is that mastery can be defined as being one of the best, for lack of domething more specific. This means, by my first point, having the required characteristic(fine motor control) and spending more time than anyone else. By spending 10000** hours you practically guarantee you have spent more time than the vast majority.Most people can’t devote 10000 hours to hone one skill. Instead, average people spread them out over many different things, becoming average in everything. *I personally believe that certain people(geniuses) learn much faster than normal people. Thus, they may take significantly less time acheive mastery. However, thousands of people who are not geniuses still acheive mastery in their fields so my premise still makes sense. **I use 10000 hours but there’s no definite number. As i pointed out, it’s the time needed to be better than most people.

When you consider your life as a whole, it is bound to be full of ups and downs and in a lot of ways that is the essence of life. In a life where you haven’t failed at all is one where you haven’t tried anything new at all. That is something alarming. Anytime you think of taking a risk; it is given that there is a solid chance of failure at the end. But you still got to do it, not just for the sake of experiencing things but for the need to get ahead. Learning is achieved through failures and downfalls. The will to stand back up and keep going at it is what defines your character. The Back Story Completing a full-length marathon has always been a pipedream for me, and at a certain point of time, I decided I was going materialize and worked towards realizing it. I started working towards the ultimate goal and completed a half marathon in October 2016. The success probably got to me as I decided on an impulse to go for a full marathon within just two months. The glory was perhaps what I was eyeing, and I failed to see the bigger picture – the training and back-end work one has to put up before being confident about my readiness to run. Needless to say, I wasn’t able to complete it that year. Fast forward a year - in 2017 I was now determined to overcome all my shortcomings from the previous year. But what I completely overlooked was one of the most essential elements – Discipline! Training for a marathon requires a lot of strength training and conditioning, almost as much if not more than the actual run. I started training quite late and then haphazardly. One important thing to remember when you are training for anything the way is to go step by step. You run 10 miles on one day; then you cannot possibly expect to do 20 miles next week. It is always a gradual process, requiring daily efforts. The old tale of a hare and tortoise tells us to win races by being slow and steady, but I took the rabbit’s way. I went in it hard and fast and ended up hurting my knee just a few shy of the race day. The wait extended by a year! “Why do we fall? So that we can learn to pick ourselves up.” -Batman Begins (2005) The Current Scenario The third time around and that is this year; I had learned a lot from the previous debacles. I was now determined to go beyond, cross all the obstacles and reach the destination. It was now time to take up the gauntlet and knock it of the park. This time, the training began much earlier, as planned. I went in one step at a time, progressing towards my aim one day at a time. The training gradually starts growing on you till one day it’s like an addiction. All you have to do is stay consistent, be persistent and see the progress. Every day, you have to work a little harder to go an extra minute. You can achieve that, and you will make progress for sure. How to Stay Motivated and Prepared * Building a Peer Group - Around this time, building a peer group of like-minded runners is very helpful. These peers are not only to push when you think you cannot go any further, but also to keep you motivated enough till and during the race day. Healthy competition is necessary to inch closer and closer to your goal. * Set Clear Goals - Another thing that has to be taken care of is to have a clear goal in your mind, a goal that has to be specific and achievable too. There is a thin line between achievable and going too easy. Going easy will just make you lose all your tempo, but a challenge tough to achieve but achievable nonetheless is something worth going the distance for. * Social Pressure Helps - Another thing that helped was social pressure. This year, I made a public announcement that I’ll be completing the upcoming full-length marathon. The heat of the moment announcement but it somehow build enough social pressure around me. The social pressure that helped me to keep going and kept me from quitting midway. I had to prove myself and show the world! The Day of Showdown After tireless hours of training, the day came. The day I was going to prove myself. The nervousness was evident in the air on the day of the run. Thousands just like me had come there to run. Some were there to prove a point, others just for the fun of it while a certain section was made up of people who ran as a habit and didn’t want to know otherwise. The race began, and I consciously controlled my nerves. In my excitement, I would have gone too fast at first and then would exhaust myself at the 20th mile or so. I was well aware that this was the rubber match for me and the marathon. This time, I was determined to conquer! During the run, you have to have some sort of motivation. There are a lot of ways to do that – music, talking to your peers, self- talk, etc. Self-talk is very necessary for such situations. Very often, our brain gives up way before our body actually has to. This result is human beings giving up way before their capacity. Our body is capable of going amazing lengths and staying unaffected; we are just scared to test it. Self-talk helps you tune out everyone else and focus on your own physical being. “It ain't about how hard ya hit. It's about how hard you can get hit and keep moving forward. How much you can take and keep moving forward. That's how winning is done!” -Rocky Balboa (2006) I finished the race my third time. Isn’t it said that third time’s the charm? I sure do agree with it now. The satisfaction of finally finishing it was a bit overwhelming, to be honest. When you finally accomplish a task, there is this feeling of completion and the knowledge that you don’t have to work towards achieving it again from tomorrow. However, you become more than determined to get even better the next time around.  Conclusion While running, you realize that once you are going at your absolute peak, the outcome is not going to affect you at all. Whether you finish or not, you start enjoying the moment. And at the moment, results and outcomes hardly matter. The only thing that matters is having fun, giving your absolute best and enjoying the process. For the final eventuality may last forever, but the journey is always the one that stays etched in memories.

It does and it doesn't !  you see 10,000 hour rule was tested on professional golfers, chess grandmasters, top coders etc and the conclusion was found out that "it takes 10,000 hrs to be as good as them" (aka reach professional levels)  Over time it was changed into "it takes 10,000 hours to be good in anything" which is complete BS!  You're a student, suppose you want to be good in math or any other subject. Will you spend 10,000 hours ? to put it into context, it means 8 hrs a day, 6 days a week for next 5 years!  no as it turns out there's another rule THE 20 HOUR RULE   For absolute mastery, 10,000 rule is applied but if you want to be just "good" at something, 20 hour rule is applied  it goes as "If 20 hrs are applied on a particular task, the mind will develop neurological connections to recognize the patterns"  Here's the linkand NO it isn't 20 hours long video.   P.S Upvotes appreciated

The common misinterpretation is that 10,000 hours of practice is 10,000 of repetition. Practice is continually pushing, testing and refining. It’s using feedback and input to get better. It’s trying new approaches and learning from the failures and successes. It’s not just mechanically repeating the same actions and activities over and over again. (though repetition can help with the mechanical if you’re pushing past some sort of limits to endurance, speed, weight, etc.) Some people will be able to achieve mastery in less time. Others will have trouble pushing their limits or applying the lessons-learned and it will take more total hours. In Gladwell’s book, it was really meant to highlight that what appears to be natural mastery or acumen is actually learned. That learning curve generally involves about 10,000 hours of hard work. Mastery is not a case of being “born with it”. It’s a case of dedication and purposeful practice. Some people may have natural advantages or benefits, but the work is still the biggest component. In that context, I would find it hard to believe that it didn’t work. I’ve see enough practical examples of people with natural ability who can’t translate it into mastery and those with no natural ability beyond perseverance who become experts in their fields.

Ah, the 10000 hour rule. The real life equivalent of the brute force method! I have a big problem with the rule as presented by Malcolm Gladwell. He only focuses on the "total time invested" part but forgets to separate the "time spent getting feedback and correcting the mistakes" part. You'll not be as good as Hendrix on the guitar if you do not seek feedback and correct your mistakes! You'll just end up repeating the same mistakes for 10k hours and wonder why you're not as good!  So 10k hours + feedback + corrections/adjustments = A better chance of being as good.

I think the 10,000 hour rule is an extension of this famous Bruce Lee quote; “I fear not the man who has practiced 10,000 kicks once, but I fear the man who has practiced one kick 10,000 times.” The same principle i.e. focused and deliberate practice is then applied to any skill. The point of Gladwell’s book is that the 10k hour rule is simply the initial aspect of becoming successful but it is not an automatic indicator of extreme success. He argues that it is the external factors that are necessary for a focused and practiced expert to become an outlier.

The 10K hour rule popularized by Malcom Gladwell, is largely based on the 1993 study by Ericsson et al(Page on Usc). Recent studies by Hambrick et all(Deliberate practice: Is that all it takes to become an expert?) questions the premise of this study by observing patterns in the field of chess and music. These fields were choosen as organic models to measure capability and performance. The view point they present is that success if a function of nature which involves innate talent and nuture which involves acquired capability.
